notes.text:
An update for expat is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Moderate. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Expat is a C library for parsing XML documents.

Security Fix(es):

* expat: stack exhaustion in doctype parsing (CVE-2022-25313)

* expat: integer overflow in copyString() (CVE-2022-25314)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

cwe.name: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling

notes.text: A flaw was found in expat. A stack exhaustion in doctype parsing could be triggered by a file with a large number of opening braces, resulting in a denial of service.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: This flaw affects applications that leverage expat to parse untrusted XML files. Applications which only parse trusted XML files or do not process XML files at all are not affected by this flaw.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, applications using the Expat library must be restarted for the update to take effect.
There is no known mitigation other than restricting applications using the expat library from processing untrusted XML content.

notes.text: An integer overflow flaw was found in expat. This issue affects the encoding name parameter at the parser creation time, which is often hard-coded (rather than user input), takes a value in the gigabytes to trigger, and on a 64-bit machine. This flaw can cause a denial of service.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: This flaw has been rated as having a severity of Moderate. The encoding name parameter is often hard-coded (rather than user input) and it would take a value in the gigabytes for the name to trigger this issue. The versions of `expat` as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 and 7 are not affected by this flaw as they did not include the vulnerable copyString() function.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, applications using the Expat library must be restarted for the update to take effect.
There is no known mitigation other than restricting applications using the expat library from processing untrusted XML content.
